data.text: Index
Endoscopy Reporting
1 - Inpatient/Emergency Flow
2 - Outpatient/Elective Flow
3 - Theatre/Endoscopy/A&E/Inpatient Flow Map
4 - Map of Endoscopy within 3rd floor Plan
5 - Withdrawal of Consent of an Endoscopic procedure Guideline

8 - Unit Policies and Guidelines – Section 6 – Informed Consent.
9 - Adverse Events/Incidents Flowchart

13 - Unisoft Electronic Reporting System
14 - Specimen Flow Chart
15 - Pre-Assessment Form
Purpose
The purpose of this document is to define the Operational Policy for Endoscopy Services provided by the Trust.
This Policy should be read in conjunction with the other Trust policies defined on the title page.
The objective of this policy is to enable efficient utilisation and provision of a high quality Endoscopy service.

To provide a high quality patient Endoscopy Service to the population of Mid Essex (approximately 380,000) serving both in-patient and outpatient activity. The Trust also receives a number of referrals from within the Eastern region for access to endoscopy which may not be offered elsewhere in the network, linked to our status as a cancer centre.

To provide access to Consultant Oncologists, Haematologists, Gastroenterologists, Physicians, Surgeons, and all other suitably qualified and experienced Clinicians involved in the investigation and treatment of a variety of conditions and diseases, via the endoscopy inpatient/outpatient setting.
To allow access for patients within the Mid Essex area and prevents the need for extensive travel to other endoscopy centres.
To provide high quality outpatient treatment for therapy services.
To provide an Out of Hours service for patients requiring all emergency endoscopic Procedures.

To comply with the relevant NICE guidelines, JAG (Joint advisory Group) Guidelines and GRS (Global Rating Scale) audits to ensure that a high standard of treatment and care is delivered to all patients through the unit, so that JAG accreditation can be achieved and maintained.
Introduction
The Endoscopy Unit sits within Division 2, for Surgery
The Endoscopy Unit is located on level 3 of the PFI Building. Its entrance is at A301 with Theatres and Day Stay.
It comprises:
Buzzer entry system in to the endoscopy unit
Patient reception with administration staff
Patient waiting rooms
Single sex patient changing rooms
Assessment rooms for admission & discharge of patients, ensuring patient privacy and dignity, within the pre-admission corridor.
3 procedure rooms (1, 2 & 3) each with adjacent bowel prep rooms
Capsule Endoscopy room, (Adjacent to room 1)
Decontamination room (dirty and clean rooms)
Single sex accommodation, recovery area, including kitchen & toilet/disabled facilities
Office for pre-admission telephone clinics and administration support
The principal benefit of the service to the patient, is that they are able to access both inpatient and outpatient services requiring endoscopic procedures.

It forms part of the requirements for Global Rating Scale (GRS) accreditation standards, Joint Advisory Group (JAG) accreditation standards, and provides reference materials and guidance for all users of the Endoscopy service for nursing staff, endoscopists, trainees, clerical staff and users of the service, patients.
This service is developed in line with recommendations from the following guidance:
Joint Advisory Group (JAG) and the Global Rating Scale (GRS)
NICE Guidelines for Endoscopy
Health Act 2006
NHS Cancer Plan (DOH 2000)
For all Booking, Validation, Vetting and Surveillance information please refer to the ‘Endoscopy Booking, Validation, Vetting & Surveillance Policy'.

Endoscopy is a highly technical procedural area where patients can feel vulnerable; therefore the unit strives to provide a non-judgemental patient focused environment. Our aim within the endoscopy unit is to effectively use resources and ensure patient safety by providing a high level of evidence based care throughout the patient journey. We endeavour to understand the patient as an individual and ensure their emotional, psychological, physical, cultural and religious needs and requirements are met. Communication is open and honest with all patients, relatives and staff, and conforms to high standards of confidentiality.

All Patients are cared for by staff with the relevant knowledge and skills within a pleasant, friendly and informative environment. We believe in a strong ethos of multi-disciplinary team working; supporting and respecting our patients and our staff. We value everyone's contribution and performance in delivering high quality care for our patients. We use our resources responsibly and prudently, and communicate our outcomes effectively throughout our organisation and through the national regulatory bodies i.e. Endoscopy User Group (EUG) and JAG.

Patient needs are met in a dignified and caring manner during their stay in the Endoscopy Unit and equality, privacy and dignity are maintained at all times. Our Endoscopy units promote professional development for staff and welcome suggestions from staff, patients and relatives for ways to continually improve our service.
Scope of the Service
The Endoscopy Service will run from 08:00 – 18:00 Monday – Friday, excluding Bank Holidays.
There are potentially  sessions throughout the week (3 rooms, 2 sessions, 5 days a week).
Session times are from 08:30 – 12:30 for the morning session and 13:30 – 17:30 for the afternoon session.
There are 3 sessions a day (am x3 rooms / pm x3 rooms) x5 days a week.
There is an ad-hoc Saturday session.
There is an on-call emergency bleeding rota in place running 24/7.
The staff are flexible with their working times depending on the patient needs.
The Endoscopy unit provides the following services:
Gastroscopy
Colonoscopy
Flexi-Sigmoidoscopy
ERCP performed within Theatres
EUS
PEG/JEG/PEC
Capsule Endoscopy
24hr Oesophageal pH Studies
Oesophageal Manometry
Bronchoscopy
EBUS
Therapeutic/diagnostic services e.g. Barrett's Oesophagus and Colitis Surveillance Chromoendoscopy List Endoscopic Resection, Argon Plasma Coagulation, Variceal Banding.
Inclusion Criteria
GP referral to Consultant – Patient telephoned as part of the straight to test service or seen in outpatients department and added to the endoscopy waiting list, for an appointment date
Two week suspected Cancer referral follows specified 2 week pathway for fast track diagnostics/treatment from Straight to test telephone assessment or OPA.
Tertiary Referral patients referred by Consultant to waiting list.
Nurse led Rectal Bleed clinics; referral from Consultant only and on ‘choose and book' restricted criteria.
Emergency patients admitted via A&E to wards. Referral via Lorenzo IT system as an inpatient (patient referral reviewed by gastroenterologist).
Emergency/in-patient referrals are vetted within 24hrs of referral and seen within 48-72hrs of referral dependant on the assessment of their emergency/priority.
Exclusion Criteria
Children Under the age of 16 years.
Patients requiring a General Anaesthetic and requiring their procedure in theatres.
Responsibilities
All Consultants are responsible and accountable for the service provided to patients as per Consultant contract.
All staff are accountable and responsible for patient care within the endoscopy services as per their Trust contract.
The Chief Operating Officer is operationally responsible for all decisions and/or changes made to the Endoscopy service.
The Assistant Director of Nursing for Surgery in conjunction with the Chief Operating Officer is responsible for the Nursing staff present in Endoscopy Services.
Finance leads for Endoscopy services sit within the Division of Surgery, and liaise with the Clinical Lead (CL) for Endoscopy and the Senior Sister/Lead Nurse for Endoscopy.
All patients attending the unit, whether day case or in-patients must have an accurate record of nursing care whilst in the unit.
Endoscopy manager responsibilities are to ensure that:
Endoscopy is carried out in a safe environment with adequate staffing.
Endoscopy staff have specialised education and training required.
Encourage and collate team feedback & disseminate and act on recommendations.
Staff work to most recent evidence based guidelines and policies.
Managing feedback from patients
Recruitment and retention of staff
There is training needs analysis with plan.
Provide induction for new staff.
To recognize and reward achievements of the team
There is an annual review of skill-mix within the team with action plan and workforce plans.
Procurement and management of equipment
All risks are actioned.
Endoscopist responsibilities are to ensure that:
The process of consent is followed.
Sedation is administered appropriately.
A safe and high quality endoscopy is performed.
The patient is monitored throughout the procedure.
Biopsies are taken as requested on the endoscopy request, or according to local biopsy protocol based on symptoms/indications for endoscopy (crib sheet available in each endoscopy room)
Endoscopy results are communicated clearly.
Suspected cancer cases are fast-tracked for histology
Suspected cancer patients are informed of clinical suspicion with CNS and NOK support (where available) prior to discharge from endoscopy
Suspected cancer patients have staging investigations requested (CT/MRI/CT colonography) at time of endoscopy to minimise wastage of time
Endoscopy nurse responsibilities are to ensure that:
Patients have a realistic explanation and expectation of the procedure.
Team brief and de-brief is completed.
Patient care is provided by a qualified member of staff.
Changes in the patient condition are relayed to the endoscopist.
Assistance to the endoscopist is provided.
Any samples are correctly labelled and sent to the appropriate lab.
Patients have clear understanding of post procedure instructions.
Decontamination personnel responsibilities are to ensure that:
Endoscopes are correctly decontaminated, stored and transported.
All procedures are in line with infection control policies.
There are safe practices of work i.e. PPE
Endoscopes are maintained and monitored.
All irregularities are reported to the Endoscopy manager.
5.0. Key Relationships
Key Operational Requirements
(Map of department within rd floor - appendix 4)
Reception
Pre-assessment rooms with access to telephones and ICT
Waiting area for patients
Single sex Patient toileting facilities including disabled facilities
Interview/discharge rooms for confidential, privacy and dignity conversations
Changing room / bowel preparation rooms, single sex, with toilet facilities.
Work bases for administrative staff, Consultants, Nurses, Endoscopists.
Staff rest room within Theatres
Staff changing rooms male/female with toileting facilities and shower within theatres
Endoscopy rooms x 3
Capsule endoscopy room
Decontamination room (as per specification see accompanying MEHT Decontamination Policy)
Recovery area- single sex accommodation maintained
Staff base
Trolley recovery
Sluice by recovery for commode storage
Recliner chair recovery
Patient toileting single sex facilities
Interview/discharge rooms
Catering facilities
Storage facilities for: equipment, supplies, consumables and disposables
Key Relationships with other Departments:
Radiology
Theatres
GICU/HDU
Colorectal CNS
Upper G.I. CNS
IBD CNS
Nutrition CNS
OPD
MDT coordinators
Wards
Phlebotomy
Histopathology
Pharmacy
Dietetics
Ambulance Service
Maintenance personnel
Key Requirements for Facilities Management (F.M.)
5.3.1 Fire
Fire risk assessments, review by the Fire officer and method of access in fire drill/alarm
The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures.”
(The detail of these items will then be developed as part of the separate Fire Safety Work Programme, as led by the Trust's Fire Officer.)
5.3.2 Laundry services
Clean linen will be supplied daily to the department as an arranged topping up system, by the contracted company, and stored in an allocated storeroom.
Dirty Linen will be placed in bags within the dedicated linen disposal room off the main endoscopy reception corridor in line with Trust Waste Policy
5.3.3 Sluice Facilities

Sluice facilities located by recovery will be used in accordance with infection prevention policy. Commodes required by attending patients to endoscopy, who are unable to mobilise to the en-suite toilet facilities in the bowel prep rooms, will be emptied in to the bowel prep room toilets, and the disposable bedpan, disposed of in to the orange clinical waste bags, and placed in the allocated clinical waste disposal room as per the Trust waste management policy.
5.3.3 Catering
Beverages and biscuits are available for patients post procedure.
Kitchen facilities are available for the recovery area
5.3.4 Pharmacy
Pharmacy supplies will be supplied on a “topping up” basis other than for scheduled and dangerous drugs which will be supplied on a direct requisition basis.
5.3.5 Disposal
All items for disposal will be taken to a designated Disposal Room off the endoscopy reception corridor, in accordance with Trust Waste Policy
5.3.6 Housekeeping
Cleaning will be provided Monday to Friday between 1800 and 2100 and will be checked in accordance with trust policy.
5.3.7 Portering
The portering department will undertake patient movement duties, collection and delivery services and any other ad hoc duties as requested.
5.3.8 Maintenance
Estates staff will undertake routine maintenance services, certain items of planned preventative maintenance on a cyclical basis and other ad hoc maintenance initiated on a requisition basis.
5.3.9 Materials management
A topping up service for all Supplies will be available to agreed levels
BME will provide a service for certain items as agreed, within the service Level agreement (SLA). Other items will be maintained by warranty/maintenance agreements (appendix 4)
Patient Flow
Emergency Flows: Out of hours (1800 – 0800 Monday to Friday) after consultation with the on-call endoscopist, to be contacted by hospital switchboard.
Weekend and public holidays - also after consultation with the on-call endoscopist, via switchboard.
In-Patient /Emergency Flow (appendix 1) Inpatients requiring a procedure
Out-Patient / Elective admissions Flow (appendix 2)
Theatre/Endoscopy/A&E/In-patient flows (appendix 3)
Outpatients will be telephone pre-admitted prior to the day of admission by a qualified nurse.
Outpatients will be admitted and discharged on the same day.
In a small number of cases (for example patients with post procedural complications) transfer to main inpatient ward will be required.
Supply Flow
Top up system provided by procurement management.
Weekly restocking of shelves from stock items.
Non stock items - ordering of non-stock items on an ‘as and when' needed basis from relevant suppliers via procurement and goods receiving.
Staffing
Medical/Specialist Staff
Nursing Staff
Skill mix based upon MEHT/NMC Guidelines and in accordance with BSG Guidelines on staffing for Endoscopy Departments
The Department manager (band 7) is responsible for overall efficiency supported by the Junior sister/charge nurse.

The Department manager and its staff report directly to the Endoscopy Matron who together with the Clinical Lead for Endoscopy ensures the smooth running of the department and the safety of its patients.
The decontamination Lead together with the manager and Matron ensures environmental facilities are safe and running efficiently, audited annually by an external Environmental engineer.
Access to Specialist Nurses:

table_items.text: Jenny Clark Karen Lloyd-Jones Irene Charlesworth Ext: 5010
Melanie Beeton Louise Hollingworth Helen Gibson Ext: 2099

data.text: Endoscopy rooms and recovery areas to be staffed by senior nurses trained in endoscopy procedures supported by junior staff and health care support workers.
Nurses trained in decontamination processes of endoscopes to staff the reprocessing area.
Staff will rotate through all areas of the unit and should be competent to work in all clinical areas where required.
At a junior level staff will be trained to work in any area of the unit covering all basic procedures as appropriate.
More experienced staff may be encouraged to develop sub-specialist skills in particular advanced procedures.
A multi-disciplinary team approach – ensuring effective communication.
All staff will adhere to BSG Guideline & unit policies.
There is an annual ‘away-day' in the form of one or two days where staff meet offsite to discuss current ways of working, service developments required and improvements that could be introduced.
Staff banding and current establishment is as shown:
Training and Education
Staff Training will be delivered in line with the Mandatory Training Policy and Training Needs Analysis.
All specialist staff training to be competency based.
All staff to have up to date mandatory training within working hours.
All staff will attend Trust Mandatory Training Days as specified.
In addition, education for nursing and support staff within the Endoscopy Services is the responsibility of each staff member, utilising both in-house and external resources.
There is a designated GIN facilitator for arranging staff to attend Endoscopy GIN courses as part of their unit specific training.

All staff are part of a designated HR team lead by a band 6, this lead mentors the team members, appraisers the team annually and ensures their mandatory/specific training needs are met and addresses any sickness or performance issues.
It is the responsibility of the management team to encourage and support “lifelong learning” as identified in each staffs' appraisal.
The hospital has a library facility for the use of all staff.
The Training and Development Department is accessible via the hospital intranet service, and has e-learning facilities, also National conferences for example B.S.G. and GIN courses are attended.
All members of staff are automatically entered onto a Trust induction programme and then a local induction programme within the endoscopy department.
Staff Facilities
All facilities are now shared within theatres department with:
staff changing rooms
male/female with toileting facilities
shower facilities
lockers
Access to training room/facilities.
Environmental Requirements
Decoration and colour scheme for clinical areas should be in line with Trust corporate approach but must be open and friendly for users.
The Endoscopy Unit has air conditioning, similar to that in theatres and has been deemed safe and policy adherent by the Infection Prevention team.
Decontamination rooms as per Health Tendering Notes (HTMs) and Health Building Notes (HBNs), see accompanying MEHT Decontamination Policy, and is managed by the Decontamination Lead.
Access to private areas/rooms to conduct sensitive conversations in close proximity to where the patient is being seen, adhering to the Trust Privacy and Dignity Policy.
All changing areas and recovery areas adhere to the Trust same sex policy to ensure patients' privacy and dignity are protected at all times.
Patient Way finding
There is a designated endoscopy reception area, down the left hand pre- assessment corridor, after entering A301 entrance via the buzzer/intercom system.
Single sex patient changing/toilet facilities, are opposite the endoscopy reception.

Patients are taken to along to the bowel prep rooms adjacent to the endoscopy procedure rooms 10-15mins prior to their procedure, to give them time to change in to a gown if necessary, ensuring the patients privacy and dignity.
After their procedure, Patients are taken from rooms 1, 2 or 3 through the theatre entrance and around to the recovery area.
Ward staff will bring inpatients to endoscopy via the theatre corridor opposite A304. This entrance is also used for portering staff, Linen deliveries, X-ray staff etc.

Patients leave the department after being discharged by their nurse, and given all their post procedure information and emergency contact information via the pre-assessment corridor and A301 entrance. (Appendix 3 patient Flows).
All information given to the patient pre and post procedure is discussed in the admission/discharge rooms to ensure confidentiality, privacy and dignity.
Patient Information

Patient information is reviewed and updated annually. This is authorised via the Patient information Group and available in the unit, in clinics and on the internet via the EIDO system. Patients also have the relevant information for their procedure sent out with confirmation of their appointment
All patients are requested to complete a patient questionnaire at the end of their procedure to hand in or post back to the department, as part of our feedback improvement system and a JAG requisite.
All patients are offered to leave their contact details if they wish to attend any of our twice a year patient forums for patient experience feedback
10 patients a month are telephoned after their procedure for an aftercare follow-up call, to gain feedback to improve our service.
A Patient survey is conducted twice a year to also gain feedback on different factors of the service, for which we would like feedback to act upon.
A Patient forum is also conducted twice a year to gain feedback from patients that have experienced the endoscopy process to feedback information necessary to improve the service further.
Emergency Requirements
All Endoscopy rooms, bowel prep rooms and toilet facilities must have an emergency call bell.
The Resuscitation Trolley must be checked and ready for use at any time in accordance with the Resuscitation Policy.
In the event of a cardiac arrest staff must call 2222, for a fire 2999 and for security
ICT Requirements
The Endoscopy department and administration team will require access to computers, printers and the following hospital based facilities:
Lorenzo
Infoflex
PACS
MEHT Review
Tomcat
Theatreman
Unisoft - Endoscopic reports and images
Email
Internet and intranet
N.B Other systems may be needed and these above are for illustrative purposes.
Tracking of scopes used per procedure /patient for infection control and as required for JAG registration.
The ability to produce information (electronic or printed) for patients on their condition and the further treatment they will receive.
Telephones.
Faxing and printing capacity.
Equipment Requirements
The following equipment is required in the Endoscopy department:
Endoscopes/ Bronchoscopes/Gastroscopes/Colonoscopes/EUS scopes/Duodenoscopes
Scope storage cupboards with forced filtered air
Associated video equipment
Associated processors/ light sources / screens
AER washer disinfectors to latest specifications
Patient trolleys
Resuscitation trolley
Diathermy units
Monitoring equipment per bay and procedure rooms
ICT equipment as stated in 8.1
Couches (x1) for each Bowel prep room
Changing rooms for patients
Changing rooms for staff
Pre-assessment/Audit/Sisters Office
Commode (x1) for patients unable to use bowel prep room toilet facilities
Single sex Recovery areas each with 8 cubicles, & recliners for step down recovery
Seating area beyond each single sex recovery area for patients to sit clothed, until ready for discharge and offered drinks and snacks
Admission/Discharge rooms x2
Storage rooms for consumables/Linen
Disposal rooms for waste
Kitchen area with dishwasher facilities
Information Security
Patient identifiable data or sensitive data must never be emailed out of the trust unless the information is encrypted or sent from and to an nhs.net account.
Patient information must never be downloaded onto any unencrypted mobile device.
All routine sharing of patient information must be agreed with a signed Data Sharing Agreement.
All staff must adhere to the Trust Information Governance and IT Security policies listed in the Information Governance Handbook.

Patients on arrival to the department are requested to buzz into the department and then take a seat in the corridor until any patient standing at reception has completed their business. This is to ensure confidentiality of patient information at the reception desk, and maintain all patients attending the department have their own privacy and dignity respected.
Medical Records
Patients Medical notes must be stored in a designated safe secure area within the endoscopy department.
Patient information must be secure at all times within the department.
All staff must adhere to the Trust Health Records Policy and Casenote Tracking Policy.
Consent
All patients consent to treatment in line with the Trust Consent Policy.
It is the responsibility of staff providing treatment or care to a patient with capacity to ensure that valid consent has been obtained from the patient before providing that treatment or care.
Records of competency to take delegated consent for doctors in training will be maintained by Medical Resources. (See Appendix 7 - Procedure Specific Delegated Adult Consent Competency Assessment)
The Lead Clinician is responsible for training and assessing the competency of any nursing staff required to take delegated consent. Competence must be recorded in accordance with the Consent Policy.

All staff should attend training in accordance with the Training Needs Analysis. Staff should refer to the Mandatory Training Policy for further details and undertake any required competencies where their role involves seeking delegated consent.

Staff have a legal duty to have regard to the provisions of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 and the Code of Practice when they have to take decisions on behalf of a person who lacks the mental capacity to take that decision for himself. (See Appendix 6 - Procedure for Patients Who Are Unable to Sign Their Own Consent Form)
Patients have the right to withdraw their consent at any stage during their treatment as per guidelines. (See Appendix 5 – Withdrawal of Consent of an Endoscopic procedure Guideline)
All staff must refer to the Endoscopy Unit Policies and Guidelines – Section 6
– Informed Consent. (Refer to Appendix 8)
20.0. Contingency
In the event of an incident the service would refer to the Trust Incident Policy, and the Business Continuity Policy.
In the event of the decontamination room having equipment failure and being unable to provide disinfected scopes, no endoscope will be used in a body cavity.
In the event of the computer system not being available for results, the relevant department would be contacted by phone.
In the event of the Trust telephone system being unavailable, Trust policy regarding internal incident or business continuity would be followed.

In the event of a shortage of specialist staff able to carry out the relevant procedures, temporary staff allocated by the Staff bank or another outside agency will be requested to backfill these shortages. Where this is not possible, endoscopy lists may be lost or re-arranged for alternatives sessions or dates.
In the event of IT failure, paper documentation is completed and uploaded when IT systems are re-established.
Auditing this Policy

Breaches of this policy will be reported via the Datix web system where trends can be identified and brought to the attention of the management and clinical stakeholders. This will include failure/breakdown of equipment impairing service delivery, management of staff sickness and resultant treatment capacity deficits.
Directorate Governance Group Meetings will be supplied with datix trend data, and incidents requiring immediate assessment will be fed back directly.

Endoscopy User Group meetings held monthly with all staff, management and clinical stakeholders represented. The aim of these meetings is to share best practice, shape service development and actively monitor risks and performance and feed directly in to the Service.

Auditing of the Endoscopy department via JAG, GRS, CQC and MEHT Infection prevention policies, ensures that this department reaches the necessary requirements for the relevant accreditation and standards of Practice.
Adverse Events
If any of the adverse events that are listed below are encountered (by any member of staff) then a Datix form is completed and submitted through the usual channels.

The unit manager should be informed, and where appropriate a datix incident form should be completed. These are collected and reviewed during the monthly EUG meetings where they are discussed and action plans are determined. Any bleeds or complications admitted after an endoscopic procedure will be entered as an adverse event and the original endoscopist will be informed.
All adverse events are responded to and actioned within 3 months of a report. (See Appendix 9 – Adverse Event/Incident Flowchart)
Endoscopy Adverse Event Definitions:
Use of flumazenil, naloxone or other reversal agent - Any patient requiring an agent to reverse the effects of sedation at any point during the procedure or stay within the endoscopy unit.
Use of midazolam > 5mg or fentanyl > 100mcg - Any patient given sedation in excess of the quantities stated above.
Perforation - Any patient with an upper gastrointestinal or colonic perforation (including those treated endoscopically).
Bleed caused by endoscopy requiring blood transfusion - Any bleed occurring after biopsy or any therapeutic procedure requiring a blood transfusion.

Bleed caused by endoscopy requiring hospitalization - Any bleed occurring after biopsy or any therapeutic procedure requiring an unplanned hospital admission (even if blood transfusion is not required).
Persistent hypoxia - Persistent fall in oxygen saturation levels below 90% (despite oxygen therapy)
Persistent hypotension requiring treatment - Any persisting hypotensive episode requiring intravenous fluid resuscitation or premature termination of the procedure.
Unplanned admission - Any patient requiring admission to hospital due to unforeseen events (e.g. Complications of the procedure or unplanned admission for monitoring post sedation).
Unplanned operation - Any patient requiring operative intervention following an endoscopic procedure (e.g. for perforation or uncontrolled haemorrhage).
Unplanned radiology or radiological intervention - Any patient requiring radiological imaging to exclude perforation (e.g. CXR, AXR or CT imaging) or intervention to treat uncontrolled haemorrhage.
Withdrawal of consent - Any patient who withdraws consent during the procedure but who the endoscopist does not appropriately terminate the procedure (see withdrawal of consent guidelines).
Cardiac arrest call - Any patient for which a cardiac arrest call is required.
Any accidental injury - Any accidental injury occurring.
Drug administration error - If an incorrect drug is administered to the patient or if there is any discrepancy in the dose of drug given or number of drug vials recorded.

Procedure performed by unapproved personnel - Any personnel undertaking a diagnostic or therapeutic procedure for which they are not accredited or appropriately supervised. Any person handling controlled drugs without appropriate training or authorisation.
Equipment failure - Any piece of equipment or device that fails (eg: endoscope or cleaning equipment).
Any other medication related complication - Any other medication related complication not encompassed above.
Any other endoscopy related complication - Any other endoscopy related complication not encompassed above.
Comfort Monitoring and Reporting
Patients comfort levels are monitored during each procedure and documented on a comfort score chart.
When a patient's comfort level falls below the agreed guidelines, staff must refer to the comfort level flow chart (See Appendix 10).
Comfort levels are discussed at EUG and Quality Circle Meetings and action plans agreed if necessary.
Supporting Endoscopist Performance and Escalation Processes
Endoscopy trainers should have completed a ‘training the trainers' (TTT) or (preferably) a training the endoscopic trainers (TET) course.
There is a matrix of endoscopic competence and accredited procedures to be undertaken displayed in the endoscopy room.

Numbers of procedures, sedation levels, completion rates, comfort scores and patient acceptability (for colonoscopy) will be audited twice yearly as part of GRS comfort audit. Results will be fed back within 3 months of the audit by the lead clinician for training.
If audit results fall outside the expected range (see below) a meeting will be arranged with the consultant and training lead to discuss possible reasons for ‘outlying results'.
A review of the endoscopists previous 3-6 months procedures will be done.
Attendance at endoscopy lists with colleagues (and access to scope guide where possible) will be encouraged.
Attendance at a colonoscopy improver's course or observer at a colonoscopy training course should be arranged.
A further audit of scores will be performed within 6 months.
If scores remain unacceptable, results will be discussed with Endoscopy services manager and arrangements made for further endoscopy training.
A further audit of scores will be performed within 3 months.

If scores remain unacceptable, the endoscopist will be advised not to continue with endoscopy procedures and the list re-allocated or the individuals practice will be reviewed by the Trust Clinical Governance/
Risk committee.
Criteria for independent colonoscopy practice (including BCS guidelines)
Unadjusted caecal intubation rate of 90%
Lifetime perforation rate less than 1 in 1000
Adenoma detection rates >20%
Maximum sedation rates less than 5mg midazolam, 50mg pethidine or 100mcg fentanyl in patients under 70 years (50% less of above in patients over 70 years).
Patient comfort scores

It is difficult to set specific criteria for ‘acceptable' comfort scores during colonoscopy. At each audit, patients will be asked to assess overall discomfort on a scale from 1-5 (five being most uncomfortable) AND whether the procedure was acceptable or unacceptable and whether they would have the procedure again.

The training lead will review all audit results and give feedback on individual and overall results. If an individual has results divergent from the mean, a more detailed review of their colonoscopy outcomes for the previous months will be undertaken as above.
Newly appointed endoscopists/ locum appointments

Newly appointed or locum staff will be asked to provide evidence of endoscopic experience and JAG certification. They will be assessed by a member of staff at the beginning of their appointment before working independently and be included in audits. Any areas of concern will be managed as above.
Please refer to Section 10 of the ‘Unit Policies and Protocols' for Colonoscopist Performance.
Referrals Vetting and Validation

All referrals will be added to Lorenzo and vetted by an endoscopist. Those who for valid clinical reasons need to be on specified operators' lists will be listed. (See Appendix  – Consultant Vetting of Referrals).
Referrals will only be accepted when accompanied by relevant clinical information and having been vetted indicating clinical priority of the procedure.
Referrals that do not meet these criteria will be returned to the referring clinician.

Referrals to be added to the pooled endoscopy waiting list daily. The clinical referral date (CRD) should be the date of the outpatient clinic generating the referral or the date a direct access referral was made.
Surveillance referrals will be validated clerically and clinically 2 months prior to the due date and before action is taken to appoint.
Routine referrals will be filed and reviewed daily to monitor time to component breach.
Requests to expedite should be made in writing. The request and original referral will be given to a clinician who will make the decision to amend from routine to urgent if appropriate.
If ANY endoscopy request is downgraded after vetting, particularly of USC referrals, then a letter MUST be sent to the referring doctor informing them of this decision and outlining the reasons why.
All inpatient referrals to be triaged by a consultant before listing.
Waiting lists will be reviewed daily & validated to ensure that the booking process has been implemented appropriately.
Please refer to separate policy ‘Endoscopy Booking, Validation, Vetting and Surveillance' policy.
Endoscopy Reporting

Endoscopy requests (i.e. via GP / Consultant letters or endoscopy request forms), should clearly state the referring clinician. A copy of the endoscopy report should be sent to the referring clinician immediately after the procedure.

The endoscopy report should contain a clear management plan within the free-text comments section. If the management plan is dependent on biopsy results, this should be documented. The management plan requires the endoscopist to understand the clinical background to the endoscopy request (which should clearly ask a question (e.g. ‘what is the cause of this patients' diarrhoea?', ‘are there polyps present?') or request an action (e.g. ‘remove this polyp). The management plan should indicate appropriate follow-up plans based on current guidelines (e.g. ‘normal colonoscopy; symptoms likely to be due to IBS; symptomatic treatment; no hospital follow-up', ‘surveillance colonoscopy in 3 years'.

The histology request should have the endoscopist recorded as the consultant or nurse endoscopist, to ensure that reports come back to the endoscopists. If the endoscopist is on leave etc. other endoscopists will review the histology's to ensure there are no urgent results. The endoscopist will act on all results on the day of review. All histology reports must be seen and acted on within 5 working days of receipt. This is the responsibility of the endoscopist.
If there is a suspicion of malignant histology the result is a referral to the MDT team, including the appropriate Clinical Nurse Specialist.
On receipt of a histology result confirming malignancy an immediate referral to the appropriate MDT at Broomfield Hospital is made.

All cancer pathology cases are referred to the upper GI, lower GI or HPB MDT meetings. Patients are informed on the day of the procedure of the suspicion or finding of cancer unless it is not in the interests of patients and this is documented in the patient record.
A copy of the endoscopy report, including the follow up plan, and procedure specific aftercare advice (including 24 hour number for advice) is given to the patient on discharge with explanation.
Patients are informed from who, and when results of specimens will be available. If a copy of the endoscopy report is not given to the patient the reason must be documented in the patient record.
A copy of the report is sent to the referrer and patient GP on the day of the procedure.
The unit uses the Unisoft Reporting System. (See Appendix  – Unisoft Electronic Reporting System).
See appendix  – Specimen Flow Chart
Please refer to the Policy ‘Specialist Upper GI Cancer MDT Operational Policy' for MDT referrals.
Privacy, Dignity and Security

The unit prides itself on optimising our patients' privacy and dignity throughout their time with us. Changes in practice are adopted from information received directly from patients via the suggestion box and patient satisfaction audit. (See Appendix  – Privacy and Dignity Policy – Essence of Care)

No patient identifiable material should be easily visible to other patients or relatives at any point during the patient journey; from the time patients arrive in reception to discharge post procedure. This includes white boards and theatre lists.

Only patients undergoing colonoscopy are changed out of their clothes - into gowns, just prior to their procedure. This is done in a changing area. They change out of the gowns post procedure in private. There are toilets near all stages of the patients' journey.

Each procedure room has a sign on the door asking staff not to enter during procedures, unless there is an urgent reason. There are phones in the endoscopy theatres but these are on silent. Elsewhere every effort is made to talk about patient related information in a discrete manner.
Additional equipment is sought if needed according to patient need e.g. hoists.

There are 2 private admission rooms where staff obtain further details prior to the procedure and are utilised to provide additional privacy for vulnerable adults, to break bad news etc. post procedure.
There are 6 recovery bays (with curtains and monitoring) and a second stage seating area.

Relatives can wait in the patient waiting area if possible and appropriate, but are not allowed into the recovery area. Conversations with relatives (if agreed by the patient) take place in the ‘admission' rooms.
It is assumed that all patients wish to have their clinical care discussed in private unless they ask to have relatives with them.
Entry into the Endoscopy department is via a buzzer entry system.
All staff follow the Trusts Safeguarding policies.
Aftercare

There are 24 hour contact numbers for patients; this will be written on all discharge information leaflets. Monday to Friday 8am to 5pm 01245  and for out of Hours Contact ring Broomfield hospital switchboard on 01245 362000 and ask to be put through to the endoscopy on-call Nurse.
Patients will be given a report and informed about their procedure. This will be done in private.

If a patient is found to have malignancy then biopsies that have been taken will be ready in approximately 10-14 days. In the meantime patients will be offered to have a CT scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis to assess further. Patients will receive an appointment for this scan through the post which can take up to 2 weeks. Once the biopsy results are back and the CT scan has been done this will then be discussed in the MDT meeting.
Decontamination
Please refer to the Endoscopy Departments separate ‘Decontamination' Policy.
Pre-Admission
All patients are telephoned prior to their appointment to complete a pre- admission telephone assessment. This is completed via written paper and documented on Lorenzo.
Refer to appendix  – Pre-Assessment Form.
References
British society of Gastroenterology(BSG) Joint Advisory Group(JAG)
Global Rating Scale(GRS)
HTM 2030
National Cancer Plan (DOH, 2008)
Appendix 1 - Inpatient/Emergency Flow
Referral received by Endoscopy department for Endoscopic procedure for an inpatient via Lorenzo from inpatient ward/A&E.
Referral vetted by Endoscopy Consultant named on vetting rota
Inappropriate referral – Inpatient ward informed by Endoscopy ward
Vetted as non-urgent – ward informed
Patient will be contacted by Outpatient Endoscopy.
Referral given to Endoscopy admin.
Appropriate referral –
Endoscopy nurse phones ward & arranges time & date and instructs bowel prep, details added to wards Lorenzo system.
Porter brings patient from inpatient ward to Endoscopy Department
Patient taken to Endoscopy procedure room on bed
Post procedure patient taken to Endoscopy dept. recovery area
When recovered patient returned to inpatient ward by Nurse and a Porter or two Nurses
Appendix 2 - Outpatient/Elective Flow
Patient arrives and books in at reception.
Patient waits in waiting area. Staff informed
Admission nurse calls patient through to admission room to complete necessary paperwork.
OGD patients wait in dept. waiting area. Nurse takes patient from waiting area to procedure room at appropriate time
Patient taken to recovery area post procedure
When recovered patient has tea and biscuits in recovery area
Patient is discharged with Paperwork.
WITH Sedation - and accompanying person
NO Sedation - with or without accompanying person
Lower Endoscopy procedure - patients wait in dept. waiting area.
Nurse takes patient from waiting area to preparation room at appropriate time.
Patient taken from preparation to procedure room
Patient taken to Endoscopy recovery area post procedure
When recovered patient has tea and biscuits in recovery area
Patient is discharged with Paperwork.
WITH Sedation - and accompanying person
NO Sedation - with or without accompanying person
